div1.p: This document describes items related to yellow fever in detail; including letters, reports, medical charts, medals, artifacts, books, photographs, interview transcripts, magazines, and sketches.

div1.head: List of items related to yellow fever in the possession of Philip Showalter Hench, by [Philip Showalter Hench], [19--]

list.head:
SOME ITEMS IN THE COLLECTION OF DATA ON THE CONQUEST OF
YELLOW FEVER NOW IN THE POSSESSION OF DR. PHILIP S. HENCH.
MAYO CLINIC, ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
Items concerning Major Walter Reed, Doctors Jesse Lazear,
James Carroll, Aristides Agramonte, and the volunteers
for the yellow fever experiments.
list.item:
1. Original letters of Walter Reed to his fiancé (1875) and letters written later
(1879) when he was stationed at western Army posts after he married Mrs. Reed.
(Many such letters).

2. Original letters of Reed to Mrs. Reed June 1900 to February 1901, written from
Camp Columbia, Cuba describing the day by day progress of the yellow fever ex-
periments. Describing of first, and later successful cases; description and
drawings, in Reed's own hand, of the little experimental buildings.

3. The original of the famous, oft-quoted “New Year's eve letter” from Reed to Mrs.
Reed, written just before, at and after midnight, December 31, 1900 - January 1,
1901, in a mood of exaltation and thankfulness to God for the successful con-
clusion of their work.

4. Fragments of the last three letters (only ones remaining) written by Doctor
Lazear to his wife; written from Cuba the last two months of Lazear's life. In
the last one he admits to secret successful experiments “of which I have told
nobody, not a soul.” (Originals)

5. The actual charts of the experimental cases of yellow fever, including the fever
charts of Carroll, the first experimental case, of “XY” (Private Dean) the
second case, of Lazear (fatal case) and later cases including those of Kissinger
and Moran, the first two soldiers who volunteered to Reed for the conclusive
experiments.
6. Telegram to Mrs. Lazear announcing the death of Doctor Lazear, September 25, 1900.

7. Special Congressional medal presented posthumously to Reed. Each of the surviving
members of the Army Yellow Fever Board and the volunteers received one such medal.

8. The Walter Reed Medal presented to Mrs. Reed by the American Society of Tropical
Medicine.
9. Small hand microscope of Doctor Lazear, undoubtedly used in Cuba.

10. The small, badly battered little smokestack (only about 7 inches long and 5 inches
in diameter) from “Building Number One”, the experimental building in which it
was proved that fomites are non-infectious. The whole theory of the infectivity
of “fomites” (clothes, personal belongings, household objects, etc.) which was
held for so many years and which cost millions and millions of dollars to sup-
port--this theory “went up in smoke” through this very smokestack.

11. A very short biographical sketch written by Carroll in his own handwriting; a
letter.
12. Letters of Agramonte defining the role he played in the experimental work.

13. Reprints of Finlay (whose theory Reed et al proved) written before the work of
the U. S. Arym Yellow Fever Board.

14. The collective works of Finlay (one volume) including the original paper on
the mosquito hypothesis.

15. Senate Document No. 61, the memorial volume published by the United States
Government which includes all the papers of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board.
This particular copy (my personal copy) is autographed here and there by most
of the survivors who took part in the experiments.
16. Dozens of other letters by Reed, Lazear, Carroll, Agramonte, etc. Originals.

17. Lazear's school books, used when he was a boy in preparatory school, Trinity Hall,
at Washington, Pennsylvania, and many original photograpsh of Lazear as boy,
student and physician.
18. Mrs. Walter Reed's scrap book concerning her husband, mostly newspaper clippings.

19. Many old original photographs of Reed, Lazear, Carroll, Agramonte and others,
mostly unpublished, including one small one of Reed in civilian clothes on board
ship, enroute to Cuba to begin the yellow fever work.
20. Reed's captains bars, embroidered shoulder insignia for formal uniform.

21. Paper cutter presented to Mrs. Reed made from wood from the little building
where Reed was born, in Belroi, Virginia.

22. All of Reed's diplomas and certificates (college, medical school, hospitals,
honorary degrees) including Reed's diploma from the University of Virginia.
I have originals and photostatic copies.

23. Inumerable, photographs, old and new, showing the places and buildings in Cuba
where Lazear, Reed, and their associates performed their experiments at the
Camp Columbia Post Hospital, the Camp Lazear, etc. These include old Army
photographs taken in 1900 and many photographs taken by me in 1938 and 1940.

24. Photastats of the old diary or “day book” of the owner of the property rented
to Reed which became “Camp Lazear”. It was our discovery of this diary which
gave us the final proof that we had discovered the “lost Camp Lazear” after
40 years of neglect.

25. Photostats of Reed's last paper written just before he died and never published
in full. Part of it was used as his last published paper.

26. Photostats of one of the two “lost laboratory notebooks” of Lazear and Reed;
about 100 pages.

27. In addition, over 20 box files (D-T invoice files) with copies of hundreds of
documents, manuscripts, reports by and about Reed and his associates; mostly
copies (photographs and photostats) of the original official Army or Governmental
reports, orders and documents, concerning the conquest of yellow fever.

28. The original check book with stubs, entries, etc., used by Major Kean to pay
Reed's volunteers and the expenses of Camp Lazear.

29. Letters of Lazear to his mother from the year 1890 to September 18, 1900, the
day he developed his fatal illness. These include the last letter written from
Cuba before his death. Mostly personal data. He did not write of his experi-
ments to his mother lost he frighten her. Lazear took sick September 18 and
died September 25, 1900. In addition, a few boyhood letters of 1875 and 1876.

30. Unpublished manuscripts by Kissinger, one of Reed's volunteers telling of his
experiences in developing experimental yellow fever.
31. Same for Moran, another volunteer.
32. Same for Andrus, another volunteer.
33. Same for Bullard, a late volunteer.
34. Stenographic interview between me and Doctor Cooke, an early volunteer.
35. Same for Doctor Pinto, an early volunteer.

36. Original description of Reed's fatal illness and death, typewritten and signed
in 1901 by the Army Surgeon in charge.
37. Autographed photograph of Carroll.
38. Autographed photograph of Agramonte.

39. Original handwritten brief report of Carroll to the Surgeon General, August 29,
1906, reviewing his own (Carroll's) part in the experiments.
40. Typewritten interviews between Walter Reed's son and daughter and myself.
41. A few original letters of Doctor Finlay.
42. Some original letters of Gorgas and of General Leonard Wood.
43. Autographed photographs of Gorgas.

44. Original reprints and copies of some of the original medical magazines including
all the papers by Reed and his associates. These include copies of the original
medical magazine with the “Preliminary Reports” of the Yellow Fever Board by
Doctor Reed to Lazear's mother and wife after Lazear's death. This also in-
cludes a reprint of the famous “Preliminary Reports” autographed and presented
to me by Mrs. Lazear.

45. Letters between Reed and Dr. L. O. Howard, the famous entomologist who cooperated
with Reed in developing methods to eradicate mosquitoes.
46. A special large file of letters from Moran, an early volunteer.
47. The same from Kissinger, an early volunteer.

48. Photostats of many 1000 - 1901 Cuban and American newspapers with editorials,
news items, etc., first scoffing at Reed's work, later grudgingly accepting it.

49. A large file of correspondence with General Jefferson Randolph Kean, who as
Major Kean, was one of Reed's right hand men in Cuba during the experiments.

50. Another large file of correspondence with General Truby, who as Lieutenant
Truby, was commanding officer at the Camp Columbia Post Hospital in Cuba
where the Yellow Fever Board did its first work.

51. Diary of Lazear's mother 1894 - 1895, when she and Doctor Lazear, her son,
took a European trip for pleasure and for some research work by Doctor Lazear.

52. The Dr. Howard A. Kelly collection of letters, papers, notes, etc., from which
he prepared his book “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever” in 1905.

53. The Peabody collection, many items, letters, clippings, etc., concerning the
volunteers. The data he collected was in part the basis for the Senate bill
which belatedly gave pensions and medals to the volunteers and Yellow Fever
Board members.

54. The Truby collection. All of the data (notes, photographs, and the original
manuscripts) used by General Truby as the basis of his recent book “Memoirs
of Walter Reed”.

55. The Kean collection. Some of this has been mentioned above. All the notes,
reprints, letters, memoranda, collected by General Jefferson R. Kean, who as
Major Kean, was Reed's “right hand man” in Cuba.
56. A few letters between Reed and Theobald Smith.
57. Unpublished manuscripts of Reed's daughter “Blossom” about her father.

58. Original cabinet photograph of Reed, the well-known photograph used for Kelly's
book.

59. The two original oil sketches, each about 2 1/2 by 3 feet (in reality finished
paintings) by the famous American artist Dean Cornwell, painted in 1940, prior
to his final version of “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”, the painting unveiled
by Blossom Feed June 1941, at the meeting of the American Medical Association.
60. A preliminary crayon sketch of Reed's head by Cornwell.

61. “Artists proof No. 1” reproduction of the final painting “Conquerors of Yellow
Fever”.

62. Original contracts between Reed and one of the volunteers, presented to me
by General Kean. Framed, about 2 by 2 feet.
63. Compilation of family records concerning the gemealogy of Dr. Lazear.
